div.head:
Embleme 9. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Shut up the tree with the old man in the house of dew, and eating
of the fruit thereof hee will become young.

lg.l: The Sophi have a tree with golden fruit,
And an old Senior of noe mean repute:
For which you must provide a house of glasse
Replete with dew, therein some time to passe:
That hee, solacing nature with that fare,
May Shake of age, and be as young men are.

div.head: Discourse 9.
div.ab:
All things whatsoever doe grow in length, breadth, and depth, that is, are
propagates, nourished, and augmented to maturity, the same things doe all
so decrease, that is, are diminished in facultyesfaculties, dyedie, and are wholly demo
lished, as is manifestly evident in all vegetables and animalls: wherefore man
allso having arrived at full growth admitts of decrement, that is, old age, whereby
his strength is gradually diminished even till the approach of death: now the
cause of old age is the same as is of a lampe decaying, and shining obscurely
the oyle being allmost consumed: For as there are three things in a lampe, the-
match, fattnessefatness, and flame, soe in man the vitallvital parts, bowells, and ligaments
are the match, fattnesse the radicall moisture, flame the naturall heat; all
the difference is that the flame of a lampe shines, the naturall heat not at all,
it not being fire, but onely heat, and that fattnesse is oyleyoily, the radicall mois
ture viscous, as being of a seminallseminal principle: As allso a lampe is extinguished
through want of oyle, soe man by old age, without any other disease, falls
into a marasme, and aged consumption, and lastly death: They relate-
of the Eagle, that in old age being hindredhindered by a crooked beake it would
be famished to death, if it were not restord by nature as it were to-
youth by casting the beake: Soe Harts seem to grow young againe by
throwing of their horneshorns, serpents their skinnsskins, and crabs their shells;-
not indeed really, because the consumed radicall moisture is not restored
to them, but as to appearance: that which can make a man grow young
againe is nothing, but death itselfe, and the begining of æternalleternal life
ensuing: as to externallexternal forme, and the restaurationrestoration of strength in-
some measure, together with the taking away of wrinkles and gray-
haires, some there are that say a remedy may be found, which Lully
affirms of the Quintessence, Arnold of præpared gold: But here-
the philosophers say, that an old man, to become young, must be-
shuttshut up with a certaine tree in a house of dew, and then hee will
eat of the fruit of the tree, and soe recover youth: It is scarce be
leivdbelieved by the vulgar that such trees are now in the nature of things:
Of Myrobalans, the fruit of a tree, Physicians write wonders, as if-
they could performeperform such a thing, take away gray haires, purify the
blood, and prolong life: but these things are doubled by many men,
unlesse they are sayd to effect it by accident, as allso other things, which
purge the masse of blood from fæces mixdmixed with it, and dye gray haire
with blacknesseblackness, with which Myrobalans are reported to colour the
haire and ball of the eyes. Marsilius Ficinus in his booke of præser
vingpreserving the life of students, writes, that in order to attaine to long life
it is coḿodiouscommodious for a man dayly to sucke the milke of some certaine
beautifullbeautiful and young woman, instead of which others doe coḿendcommend
the eating of vipers flesh: but indeed these means are themselves
Discourse 9.
more rigid than old age, and scarce to be used by one of a thousand,-
though they Should not be without certaine effect: It is written by Para
celsus in his booke of long life, that a sicke man may attract to him
selfe the health of another by imagination alone, as allso an old man
youth, but this Author seems in this to use his imagination onely, not
experience: It is thing certaine of the Psylli who have two balls of the
eye, and of witches, that they bewitch children and cattle by aspect alone,
from whence that of Virgill: Nescio quis teneros oculus mihi fascinet agnos:
but these things are done without contact, whereby the tree restores the-
old man to youth: for this tree hath sweet fruit, ripe and red, which doe
easily turneturn into pure blood, being of easy digestion and excellent nutri
ment, soe as to leave nothing superfluous or fæculentfeculent in the body: but-
the old man abounds with white phlegmephlegm, and is of a white colour and-
hairy, which humor, colour, and haire are changed by eating these-
fruits, and become red, as those are of young men. For this reason say the
Philosophers, the Stone is first old, that is white, then young, that is, red, because
this is the colour of youth, as that of old age: It is added, that the old man-
ought to be ShuttShut up with the tree, not in the open aire, but in a house, not
dry, but moist with dew. It is accounted a miracle for trees to Spring or vegetate
in a close place, but if it be moist, there is noe doubt of their long duration:
for the nutriment of a tree is moisture, and airy earth, that is, fatt, which
can ascend into the trunketrunk and boughesboughs, and there produce leaves, flowers,
and fruit, in which naturall worke all the Elements doe concurreconcur, fire-
giving the first motion, as the efficient, aire tenuity and penetrability, water
lubricity, earth coagulation: for aire returns into water, and water into-
earth, if any of their superfluity ascend: By fire I meane the naturall
heat, which being propagated with the seed doth by the power of the StarrsStars
as it were a Smith fabricate and forme fruit like to those things from whence
the seed arisetharises: But a dewy evaporation is not onely good and expedient to moisten
the tree, that it may more easily yeild fruit, but allso the old man, that by
those fruits hee may become young againe, that is to say, the dewy evapo
ration mollifying, filling up, and restoring his wrinkled and dry SkinneSkin
with temperate heat and moisture: for Physicians doe advisedly and with
great utility enjoyneenjoin and præscribe warme baths in the marasme and-
aged consumption: but if the thing be well considered that tree is the-
daughter of the old man, which as Daphne is transmuted into a vegetable
of the like sort, and therefore the old man doth not without reason expect
youth from it, which caused it to be effected. . . . . . .
